text: [Music]
English like all languages is a messy
business you can be uncouth but not cth
you can be ruthless but good luck trying
to show somebody that you have Ruth
unless you happen to be married to
someone named Ruth it's bad to be
unkempt but impossible to be kempt or
shoveled as opposed to
disheveled there are other things that
make no more sense than those but that
seem normal now because the sands of
time have buried where they came from
for example did you ever wonder why a
nickname for Edward is Ned where' the N
come from it's the same with Nelly for
Ellen after all if someone's name is
Ethan we don't nickname him nethan nor
we call our favorite Maria na Maria in
fact if anyone did our primary urge
would be to either scold them or gently
hide them away until the company had
departed all these nicknames back to a
mistake although a perfectly
understandable one in fact even the word
nickname is weird what so Nick about a
nickname is it that it's a name that has
a Nick in it let's face it not likely
actually in Old English the word was
echon name and eeka meant also or other
you can see eeka still used in Cher's
canterberry tales in a sentence like one
zirus ache with his s to breath which
meant when Zephyr also with his sweet
breath
Eon name meant also name what happened
was that when people said an echon name
it could sound like they were saying a
NECA name and after a while so many
people were hearing it that way that
they started saying that's my nick name
instead of that's my EA name now the
word had a stray n at the front that
started as a mistake but from now on was
what the word really was it was rather
as if you had gum on the bottom of your
shoe and stepped on a leaf dragg that
leaf along for the rest of your life
were buried wearing that shoe and went
to heaven in it to spend eternity wedded
to that stray worn out Leaf echon name
picked up an n and never let it go the
same thing happened with other words Old
English speakers cut aches into wood but
after centuries of being asked to cut an
ACH into something it was easy to think
you were cutting a notch instead and
pretty soon you were in a world where
almost no one could read it was easy
iier for what people heard to become
after a while what it started to
actually be here's where the Ned style
nicknames come in Old English was more
like German than our English is now and
just as in German my is mine in Old
English my was mean you would say mean
book actually Boke in Old English or
mean cat and just as today we might
refer to our child as my Dalia or my
laara in Old English they would say me
mean Ed that is mine Ed mine Ellie you
see where this is going as time passed
mean morphed into the my we know today
that meant that when people said mine Ed
it sounded like they were saying my Ned
that is it sounded like whenever someone
referred to Edward affectionately they
said Ned instead of Ed behold the birth
of a nickname or an ick name hence also
so Nelly for Ellen and Nan for an and
even in the old days Nai for Abigail
President John Adam's wife Abigail's
nickname was
nabbi all sorts of words are like this
Old English speakers wore napron but a
napron sounds like an apron and that
gave birth to a word apron that no one
in bolf would have recognized umpires
started as nump Ires too if all of this
sounds like something sloppy that we
modern people would never do then think
about something you hear all the time
and probably say a whole another what's
another we have the word another of
course but it's composed of an an other
or so we thought yet when we slide whole
into the middle we don't say a whole
other we clip that n off of the an and
stick it to other and create a new word
another for a long time nobody was
writing these sorts of things down or
putting them in a dictionary but that's
only because writing is more codified
now than it was a thousand years ago so
when you see a weird word remember that
there might be a whole another side to
the story
[Music]
